turn.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to move your body so that you are looking in a different direction
turn.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She turned her head in surprise.
Brigitte glared at him, turned on her heel (=turned away suddenly because of anger), and stomped out of the room.
Dan turned away, hiding the fear in his eyes.
He turned around to look at Kim.
‘No, ’ she said, turning her head to see David’s reaction.
turn.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: to move something so that it is pointing or aiming in a different direction
turn a/the page (=move a page in a book over so that you can read the next page)
turn.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: Could you turn your chairs to face this way?
You may turn over your exam papers now.
The firemen turned their hoses on the blaze.
He turned down the corner of the sheet to peep at the baby.
turn.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to go in a new direction when you are walking, driving etc, or to make the vehicle you are using do this
turn.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: I watched until he turned the corner.
She cycled up the street and turned into Long Road.
Turning the car around, we headed home.
turn.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if a road, river etc turns, it curves and starts to go in a new direction
turn.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: Further on, the river turns east.
The road turns sharply at the top of the hill.
turn.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to move around a central or fixed point, or to make something move in this way
turn.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: The wheels turned slowly, then picked up speed.
For some reason, the key wouldn’t turn.
She gently turned the handle of the bedroom door.
turn.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to start to have a different quality, or to make something do this
turn.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: Rose’s hair was already turning grey.
In October the leaves turn orange and yellow.
The sun had turned the sky a glowing pink.
Then it turned cold and started to rain.
The police are worried that the situation could turn violent.
turn.translation[0].definitions[5].note_: Turn is a linking verb in this meaning It links the subject of the sentence with an adjective
turn.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to start to think about, deal with, look at etc a particular person, thing, or subject, instead of what you were thinking about etc before
turn.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Many investors have turned their attention to opportunities abroad.
turn your attention/thoughts/efforts etc to something/somebody
Phil turned his gaze towards the older man.
turn your attention/thoughts/efforts etc to something/somebody
As usual, the conversation turned back to her children.
Now is the time of year when thoughts turn in the direction of summer holidays.
Next the Senator turned to education.
turn.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to become a particular age, or to reach a particular time
turn.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to make or let someone or something go out from where they are
turn.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Turn the dough out onto a lightly floured board.
There are some criminals who cannot be turned loose onto the streets.
turn.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: if the tide turns, the sea starts to come in or go out again
turn.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: if something such as a war, situation, game of sport etc turns, or someone turns it, something happens to change the way it is developing
turn.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: Mills turned the game by scoring twice.
The victory turned the tide of the war in North Africa.
turn.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to break up soil so that it is ready for growing crops
turn.translation[0].definitions[11].exam: a distant tractor turning the soil
turn.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to shape a wooden or metal object using a special tool
turn.translation[0].definitions[13].defi: if milk turns, it becomes sour
turn.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: turn
to move around a central or fixed point
The wheels of the train began to turn.
go around
to turn around a central point. Go around is a little more informal than turn and is very common in everyday English
When the fan goes around, the warm air is pushed back downwards.
revolve/rotate
to turn around and around a central point. Rotate and revolve are more formal than turn and sound more technical
The Earth rotates on its axis once every twenty-four hours.
The stage revolves at various points during the performance.
spin
to turn around many times very quickly
The ice skater began to spin faster and faster.
whirl
to spin around extremely quickly, often in a powerful or uncontrolled way
The blades of the helicopter whirled overhead.
twirl (around)
to spin around quickly, especially as part of a dance or performance
The couples were twirling around on the dance floor.
swirl (around)
to move around quickly in a circular movement, especially when the movement goes outwards or upwards from the center
Her white skirt swirled around her legs as she danced.
The leaves began to swirl around.
spiral
to move in a continuous curve that gets nearer to or further from its central point as it goes around
The smoke spiralled toward the ceiling.
turn.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: the time when it is your chance, duty, or right to do something that each person in a group is doing one after the other
turn.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: It’s your turn. Roll the dice.
I think it’s our turn to drive the kids to school this week.
Whose turn is it to set the table?
turn.translation[1].definitions[0].note_: In everyday English, people often say that it is someone’s go in a game rather than turn:
turn.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: a place where one road goes in a different direction from the one you are on
turn.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: According to the map we missed our turn back there.
I think we took a wrong turn coming out of town.
take the first/a wrong etc turn
Take the second turn on the left.
take the first/a wrong etc turn
turn.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a curve in a road, path etc
turn.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: There’s a sharp turn coming up ahead.
turn.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: a change in the direction you are moving
turn.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Make a left turn at the station.
turn.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: a sudden or unexpected change that makes a situation develop in a different way
turn.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: From then on, our fortunes took a downward turn.
My career had already taken a new turn.
The president was stunned by the sudden turn of events.
Two days after the operation, Dad took a turn for the worse.
take a turn for the worse/better
turn.translation[1].definitions[5].defin: the act of turning something completely around a fixed point
turn.translation[1].definitions[5].examp: I gave the screw another two or three turns.
turn.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: the difference between the price at which a MARKETMAKER will buy and sell a particular share
turn.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: if something takes a particular turn, it starts developing in a completely different way
turn.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Things may take a bad turn and the economic situation may deteriorate.
The economy seems to be taking a turn for the worse (=suddenly becoming worse).
turn.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The China operation has just started turning a profit.
